subject: Re: [junit] How to modify JUnit output to something more readable ?
msgSnippet: Hi Kamal, you can run your ant scripts within Eclipse very easy, and browse the reports with builtin web browser widget. But, the most convenient way is to use
messageBody:
Hi Kamal,

you can run your ant scripts within Eclipse very easy, and browse the
reports with builtin web browser widget.

But, the most convenient way is to use the builtin Eclipse JUnit runners,
which allow you to run tests on packages, rerun failed tests etc. This is a
quite cool support !

Cheers, Jochen Hiller


On 7/12/06, Kamal Ahmed <KAhmed@...> wrote:
>
> Can we do something like this from Within Eclipse? As well?
> -Kamal.
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com <junit%40yahoogroups.com> [mailto:
> junit@yahoogroups.com <junit%40yahoogroups.com>] On Behalf Of Ejaz
> Nasser
> Sent: Wednesday, July 12, 2006 3:29 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com <junit%40yahoogroups.com>
> Subject: Re: [junit] How to modify JUnit output to something more
> readable?
>
> ANT build file provide answer to your question.
> If you use JUNITREPORT task with junit task to test you test cases, it
> will
> create a browsable report for you. Here is the link for it:
> http://ant.apache.org/manual/OptionalTasks/junit.html
>
> Ejaz
>
> On 7/12/06, james_adams <james_adams@... <james_adams%40yahoo.com>>
> wrote:
> >
> > I have inherited some code which runs a suite of JUnit test cases (via
> > junit.textui.TestRunner.doRun(mySuite)) and outputs the results of the
> > test case either as "." for a success, or ".F" for a failure, followed
> > by the errors and a summary of the run results. So if I have three
> > test cases in the suite, and the first and third test cases succeed,
> > then the output file looks like "..F." followed by the errors and a
> > summary of how many successes/failures. There are about 80 test cases
> > in the suite I'm working with, and it is very time consuming and error
> > prone to try to figure out which tests succeeded and which ones failed
> > from a long list of dots and dot-F's. What I would like instead is to
> > have the report look something like this:
> >
> > test-01-01: success
> > test-01-02: failure
> > test-02-01: success
> >
> > <errors>
> >
> > <summary>
> >
> > I have looked at the JavaDoc for junit.textui.TestRunner and there is
> > no way to specify how the final report comes out, more specifically no
> > way to tell it to print the name of the test case and the result
> > rather than either "." for success or ".F" for failures.
> >
> > Can anyone advise me how I can modify this behavior? Am I stuck and
> > just need to write a parser to convert the "..F." to a meaningful
> > report as to which tests succeeded or failed (as in the above example)?
> >
> > Thanks in advance for any suggestions.
> >
> > --James
> >
> >
> >
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
>
> Yahoo! Groups Links
>
>
>
